summary: Modeled and simulated a wheeled biped robot's dynamics in Mujoco, implementing balance and movement control systems.
title: MAE 3260: Simulating a wheeled biped robot
description: This was the final group project for my system dynamics class, where we modeled the dynamics of a wheeled biped robot. The two primary goals were having the robot balance without falling over, and having the robot move to a desired location. I was tasked with simulating our robot control model in Mujoco. A demo video of the final result can be found below, as well as our engineering writeup. The github repo with the simulation code is also attached.

summary: Dissected and analyzed a pneumatic impact wrench in a fluid dynamics context, calculating maximum torque of 900 lb*in.
title: MAE 3230: Pneumatic Wrench Dissection
description: We were given a pneumatic impact wrench to dissect in a fluid dynamics context. We produced a video describing the function and fluid dynamic application of the pneumatic wrench. My contributions were dissecting the pneumatic impact wrench, helping with the math to compute the maximum torque, and editing the video. We found that the pneumatic impact wrench could generate torques of up to 900 lb * in, which is comparable to electric drills.

summary: Designed a titanium torque wrench using FEM analysis in Ansys, achieving strain gauge sensitivity of 1.214 mV/V.
title: MAE 3270: Torque wrench simulation
description:
This assignment was done in collaboration with Youngjin Yang. 

# Overview 

 This project required us to design a torque wrench by choosing a material and dimensions to satisfy safety and gauge output requirements. Simulation was done in Ansys to verify our theoretical calculations. 

# FEM Analysis Results 

 ## Dimensions 

 The torque wrench center was 16 in from the end. It had a width of 1.3 in and a thickness of 0.1 in. Drawings and CAD are below.

## Material Properties

We used Ti-6Al-4V titanium alloy for the wrench. The key material properties are:
- Young's Modulus: 16.5 × 10⁶ psi
- Poisson's Ratio: 0.34
- Tensile Strength: 135,000 psi
- Fracture Toughness: 80,000 psi√in
- Fatigue Strength: 74,000 psi

## Torque Wrench Sensitivity

The strain gauge has a gauge factor of 2, and we are assuming a half bridge design. Based on the FEM strain, the wrench sensitivity is 1.214 mV/V. This passes the design requirement of an output > 1.0 mV/V

## Strain Gauge Selection

We chose the Micro Measurements 015LW strain gauge, which is a linear (uniaxial) gauge with a 0.075-inch active length and a gauge factor of 2.0. It fits easily in our design since it needs less than 0.1 inches of space. The small size works well for our application, though a larger gauge would have been easier to install if we had more room.

summary: Built a mini basketball hoop with automatic ball return using laser-cut acrylic, living hinge ramp, and 3D-printed flywheels.
title: MAE 2250: Le mini hoop
description: Le mini hoop is a mini basketball hoop with an automatic return system powered by 600 rpm motor.
This was my team project from my mechanical design class, we set out to reduce the friction of having to pick up the basketball after every shot.
The frame was laser cut with acrylic, the ramp was a laser cut out of wood with a living hinge design (to flex as a ramp), and the flywheels & gears were 3D printed with PLA.
When fully spun, the flywheels can launch the ball to the person's chest up to ~10 feet.

We ran into some roadblocks. We wanted to use a motion sensor to turn on the motor when the ball was in the funnel, but it took too long for the flywheels to spin up. So the motor was controlled with an on/off switch. Also, we didn't plan out fully how the electrical components would fit in the assembly, so there was a bit of a mess with wires in the end product.
